facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 204 of 1966 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 204 of 1966.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 10, 1965 of the Allahabad High Court in F.A. No. 213 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and decree dated March 10, 1965 of the Allahabad High Court in F.A. No. 213 of 1964.

facts.text: An election was held for one seat to the U. Legislative Council from the Rohilkhand Graduates Constituency on April 22, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: An election was held for one seat to the U. Legislative Council from the Rohilkhand Graduates Constituency on April 22, 1962.

facts.text: There were 14 candidates in the election.

anchor.surface_text: There were 14 candidates, and election was held in accordance with the system of proportional representation by means

facts.text: Election held in accordance with the system of proportional representation by means of single transferable vote.

anchor.surface_text: There were 14 candidates, and election was held in accordance with the system of proportional representation by means of single transferable vote.

facts.text: Total number of votes cast were 4412.

anchor.surface_text: Total number of votes cast were 4412 and 2207 first preference votes were required to secure the return of any

facts.text: 2207 first preference votes were required to secure the return of any candidate at the first count.

anchor.surface_text: Total number of votes cast were 4412 and 2207 first preference votes were required to secure the return of any candidate at the first count.

facts.text: No candidate secured the minimum votes at the first count.

anchor.surface_text: As no candidate secured the minimum votes at the first count, subsequent counts had to be made excluding the candidat

facts.text: Satya Ketu, respondent, got the highest number of votes after the last count and was declared elected by a margin of 47 votes.

anchor.surface_text: Eventually, Satya Ketu, respondent, got the highest number of votes after the last count and he was declared elected by a margin of 47 votes.

facts.text: Appellant filed an election petition claiming the election of Satya Ketu void and that the appellant was duly elected.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the appellant filed an election petition claiming that a declaration be made that the election of Satya Ketu was void and that the appellant was duly elected from this constituency.

facts.text: Appellant claimed invalid votes counted for Satya Ketu: ballot papers marked with figure I (Roman numeral) counted as valid under r. 73(2) of the Rules.

anchor.surface_text: The basis of the appellants claim was that invalid votes had been counted in favour of Satya Ketu inasmuch ballot papers on which figure I was numbered marked were counted as valid when they should have been counted as invalid in view of r. 73 (2) of the Conduct of Elections Rules, 1961

facts.text: Satya Ketu contended all votes counted in his favour were valid.

anchor.surface_text: Satya Ketu contested in reply that all the votes counted in his favour were valid votes and therefore prayed that the petition should be dismissed.

facts.text: Election Tribunal scrutinised ballot papers and held ballot papers with Roman numeral I invalid under r. 73(2), 491 votes invalid for Satya Ketu.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal scrutinised the ballot papers and divided them into a number of categories. It held that certain ballot papers bore the Roman numeral I instead of the Arabic numeral 1. It therefore held that ballot papers marked with the Roman numeral I were invalid under r. 73 (2) of the Rules as they did not bear the Arabic figure 1. It thus came to the conclusion that 491 votes cast in favour of Satya Ketu were invalid.

facts.text: Tribunal allowed the petition, declared Satya Ketu's election void and appellant duly elected.

anchor.surface_text: It therefore allowed the petition and declared the election of Satya Ketu, respondent, void and further declared the appellant to be duly elected from that constituency.

facts.text: Satya Ketu appealed to Allahabad High Court in F.A. No. 213 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: Satya Ketu then went in appeal to the High Court, and his contention was that the Tribunal was wrong in holding that ballot papers which had been marked by Roman numeral I were invalid.

facts.text: High Court overruled preliminary objection that appeal not accompanied by copy of decree.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court over-ruled the preliminary objection and held that no copy of decree was necessary in view of the provisions of s. 98 and s. 116-A of the Representation of the People Act

facts.text: High Court held r.73(2) does not invalidate Roman numeral I, counted 460 of 491 votes as valid, Satya Ketu wins by 16 votes, allowed appeal, dismissed petition.

anchor.surface_text: On the merits it held that r. 73 (2) did not mean that preference expressed by writing down the Roman numeral I in place of the Arabic numeral 1 would make the ballot paper on which the Roman numeral I was written invalid. It therefore counted as valid votes which bore the Roman numeral 1. Thus out of 491 votes which were declared invalid by the Tribunal, the High Court was of the view that 460 votes were valid and as Satya Ketu had won by 47 votes and would still win by 16 votes, it allowed the appeal and dismissed the petition.

facts.text: Present appeal filed by appellant with certificate from High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal has been filed by the appellant with a certificate granted by the High Court.

facts.text: No decree was actually prepared by the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that a direction was given by the Tribunal to the effect that a decree containing the details of costs should be prepared, though no such decree was actually prepared at any time.

facts.text: Supreme Court held no decree required for election tribunal orders under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that in view of the provisions of the Act it is unnecessary to prepare a decree after the conclusion of the trial of an election petition section 90 (1) would not make those provisions of the Code of Civil Procedure which require the preparation of a decree applicable to the trial of an election petition

facts.text: Supreme Court held ballot papers marked with Roman numeral I valid under r.73(2).

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the High Court that marking of figure 1 in Roman form is in full compliance with r. 73 (2) (a).

facts.text: Appeal dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal fails and is hereby dismissed with costs.

issues.text: whether a decree is required to be prepared in accordance with the judgment of the tribunal in an election petition, and if so, whether it is necessary to file a copy of such decree along with a copy of the judgment of the tribunal when filing an appeal under s. 116-A of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The question that falls for decision therefore is whether a decree is required to be prepared in accordance with the judgment of the tribunal in an election petition, and if so, whether it is necessary to file a copy of such decree along with a copy of the judgment of the tribunal when filing on appeal under s. II 6-A of the Act.

issues.text: whether votes which should have been declared invalid in view of the provision of r. 73 2 of the Rules had been counted as valid in favour of Satya Ketu, specifically whether ballot papers marked with the Roman numeral I were invalid under r. 73 2 of the Rules as they did not bear the Arabic figure 1

anchor.surface_text: Thus the main question for decision before the Election Tri- bunal  hereinafter referred to as the Tribunal  was whether votes which should have been declared invalid in view of the provision of r. 73 2  of the Rules had been counted as valid in favour of Satya Ketu. The Tribunal scrutinised the ballot papers and divided them into a number of categories. It held that certain ballot papers bore the Roman numeral I instead of the Arabic numeral 1. It therefore held that ballot papers marked with the Roman numeral I were invalid under r. 73 2  of the Rules as they did number bear the Arabic figure 1.

issues.text: whether the presence of additional words or markings besides the Roman figure I, such as 'st' or the word 'one', would invalidate the ballot paper under r. 73 2 a

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion, where figure I is marked on the ballot paper, whether it be in one form or other including the Roman form, that is in full compliance with the rule, and the ballot paper would number be invalid in the circumstances. Then it is urged that besides the Roman figure 1, some other words were added in some cases. Even if that were so, we are of opinion that r. 73 2  a  would number justify declaration of a ballot paper as invalid so long as the figure I is marked.

holdings.text: No decree is required to be prepared by the election tribunal after the conclusion of the trial of an election petition; section 90(1) does not make CPC provisions requiring preparation of a decree applicable, as trial procedure is subject to the Act; appeal under s.116A is from the tribunal's order, not decree, and requires only copy of judgment

anchor.surface_text: Subject to the provisions of this Act and of any rules made thereunder every election petition shall be tried by the tribunal, as nearly as may be, in accordance with the pro- cedure applicable under the Code of Civil Procedure,1908  5 of 1908  to the trial of suits. Sections 91 to 97 provide for certain other matters to which reference is unnecessary. Section 98 provides for the decision of the tribunal, and lays down that- At the conclusion of the trial of an election petition the tribunal shall make an order-

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory scheme of RPA Part VI: s.98 requires 'order' not decree; s.90(1) CPC 'as nearly as may be' subject to Act; s.116A appeal from order with procedure analogous to decree appeal but no decree needed; distinguished CPC ss.33,96; High Court rules Ch.XIV-A require order copy only

holdings.text: A ballot paper marked with the figure 1 in Roman numeral form (I) is valid under r.73(2)(a) of the Conduct of Elections Rules, 1961, as it indicates first preference; rule does not require Arabic/international form exclusively

anchor.surface_text: Coming now to the merits of the appeal, the whole argument of the appellant is based on r. 73 2  of the Rules, which is in these terms - A ballot paper shall be invalid on which-  a  the figure I is number marked or  b  the figure I is set opposite the name of more than one candidate or is so placed as to render it doubtful to which candidate it is intended to apply or  c  the figure I and some other figures are set opposite the name of the same candidate or

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text of r.73(2)(a) requires 'figure 1' marked for first preference, not specific form; purposive: any form showing 1 suffices; later Explanation confirms Roman/international/Indian forms allowed, reflecting original intent; rejects strict Arabic reading

holdings.text: Additional words or markings (e.g., 'st' or 'one') besides the figure 1 (including Roman I) do not invalidate the ballot paper under r.73(2)(a), so long as figure 1 is marked to show first preference

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion, where figure I is marked on the ballot paper, whether it be in one form or other including the Roman form, that is in full compliance with the rule, and the ballot paper would number be invalid in the circumstances. Then it is urged that besides the Roman figure 1, some other words were added in some cases. Even if that were so, we are of opinion that r. 73 2  a  would number justify declaration of a ballot paper as invalid so long as the figure I is marked.

holdings.reasoning_summary: r.73(2)(a) invalidates only if figure 1 absent; extra words ignored if 1 clearly marks first preference; aligns with rule purpose of ascertaining voter intent

justification_sets.label: Rule 73(2), Conduct of Elections Rules, 1961 support

anchor.surface_text: Subject to the provisions of this Act and of any rules made thereunder every election petition shall be tried by the tribunal, as nearly as may be, in accordance with the pro- cedure applicable under the Code of Civil Procedure,1908  5 of 1908  to the trial of suits. Sections 91 to 97 provide for certain other matters to which reference is unnecessary. Section 98 provides for the decision of the tribunal, and lays down that- At the conclusion of the trial of an election petition the tribunal shall make an order-

anchor.surface_text: Coming now to the merits of the appeal, the whole argument of the appellant is based on r. 73 2  of the Rules, which is in these terms - A ballot paper shall be invalid on which-  a  the figure I is number marked or  b  the figure I is set opposite the name of more than one candidate or is so placed as to render it doubtful to which candidate it is intended to apply or  c  the figure I and some other figures are set opposite the name of the same candidate or
The appeal fails and is hereby dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion, where figure I is marked on the ballot paper, whether it be in one form or other including the Roman form, that is in full compliance with the rule, and the ballot paper would number be invalid in the circumstances. Then it is urged that besides the Roman figure 1, some other words were added in some cases. Even if that were so, we are of opinion that r. 73 2  a  would number justify declaration of a ballot paper as invalid so long as the figure I is marked.
The appeal fails and is hereby dismissed with costs.
